Posts.Content: Hi LizzyRascal. I'm so glad I've helped you see that light at the end of the tunnel. I wish you well as you embark on the treatment bus. You'll be amazed at how strong you are and all the sh#%t they throw at you will become a surreal routine. Stay close to this group as you go along and the ladies and gents here will help you get through to that finish line. I have found this a great comfort as whatever emotion, symptom or situation you have you will find you are never alone. Good luck with your treatment x
Posts.Title: Fantastic News!

Posts.Content: Thanks everyone for your congratulations. I'm off now to break open the champagne! X
Posts.Title: Fantastic News!

Posts.Content: I've had the best news I've had for a whole year. Just come back from my first follow up mammogram, post treatment and it was all clear! I was so nervous waiting in the waiting room for the result I thought I was going to faint. When the nurse called me in and said it was fine the relief was indescribable! It's been a hard year with 2 WLE operations, chemo and radiotherapy and many a time it seemed it would never end. To all of you still doing battle please take encouragement from this. You are going through hell but you will have the strength to get to the other side of it and you will be celebrating like I am today. Best wishes xxxx
Posts.Title: Fantastic News!

Posts.Content: After going through treatment which finished last May, I have learn't that we aren't defined by our hair. I lost mine and quite frankly that was the least of my problems when on chemo. My hair is short but back, I am back at work and apart from Letrozole aches and pains I am  'back to normal'..... Except that I'm not. The me I was before is not the me I am now. I don't know whether I should have expected to be the same or not but I am definitely changed. It is a case of small steps and a good degree of acceptance.
Posts.Title: I'm not 'me'

Posts.Content: Hi Spenfold. Don't worry about injecting yourself, it is amazing what we find we can do and how strong we are while going through this awful treatment. I was like you at the start and went pale at the thought of giving myself an injection. I was so proud of myself when I did it for the first time. Then after my 2nd FEC I developed a pulmonary embolism and now I have to have an injection everyday for the next 6 months! The day after each chemo I do the neulastin injection so it's two that day. It's just part of the routine now. Only trouble is I'm loosing weight as my appetite's not so great and the fat reserves necessary for the injection are diminishing fast! Good luck with your injections xxx
Posts.Title: Omg injecting myself arghhh !!!

Posts.Content: Very well done to both of you! Celebrations all the way - you deserve a treat. Xxx
Posts.Title: I've only gone and done it !!

Posts.Content: This sounds exactly the same as I had and I was told this was quite a rare reaction. I urge you to see your oncologist before you have any more docetaxel as it could be dangerous to have any more! I had a severe burning skin reaction to my face, neck and hands and my mouth and lips were also badly affected. I was treated with antibiotics, antihistamines, hydrocortisone cream and moisturising lotion. It took a few weeks to improve and my chemo had to be delayed. Because of this reaction they couldn't give me any more docetaxel and changed to paclitaxol which is a milder weeklyversion. I had a problem with neutropenia on this so I was eventually put back on FEC. I got very down about all the problems and delays but fortunately it is behind me now. I hope this helps you but please see your onc as soon as possible! X
Posts.Title: Docetaxel - face and neck red - have you experienced this?

Posts.Content: Hi Bev I had a slightly sore mouth on FEC but nothing too bad and the mouthwash they gave me kept it at bay. On docetaxol however it was a different story. Awful taste very sore mouth and lips and several bouts of oral thrush. It was pretty bad at the time but I did have other bad reactions to T as well so I was unlucky. Hopefully you will get a better experience. We are all different and some folks sail through. Good luck!
Posts.Title: Sore mouth

Posts.Content: Welcome to the peach head club! Mine's coming along too but quite patchy with some baldy spots still but the doc assures me this is normal at first. My eyelashes are back and the eyebrows are coming along too. I can't wait to get rid of all these hats and scarves! Happy plucking!
Posts.Title: Hair coming back

Posts.Content: Thanks Dreamthief. It looks like Littlesusie and I have a way to go before the letrozole bomb drops then. I hope we get off lightly! I have been given calcium/vit D tablet to take as well to stop my bones turning to powder. X
Posts.Title: Letrezole

Posts.Content: I've just started taking letrozole this week. I've opted for taking it in the morning as I take another pill then so it keeps things simple an I'm less likely to forget it. Can anyone tell me when to expect the side effects to kick in? I feel ok so far but I've only had 3 pills. Thanks x
Posts.Title: Letrezole

Posts.Content: Well done. Yes you are nearly there. I finished rads yesterday and it is a good feeling. A great big WOOHOO! Xx
Posts.Title: surgery done. Nearing the end of this journey

Posts.Content: I have been doing Iyenga yoga for many years and go to a very experienced teacher. When I told her what I was currently going through she put together a program of poses especially for people going through cancer treatment. They are focused on relaxation rather than the usual strenuous poses. I can do these at home rather than going to class where I'm at risk of picking up colds etc. When I've finished chemo I will go back to my teacher and she will start rehabilitation poses. Yoga is perfect as it can be tailored to your individual needs. I wouldn't recommend doing it without a qualified teacher though as you could injure yourself. Hope this helps. Xxx
Posts.Title: Yoga

Posts.Content: It is natural to be scared as what we are going through is so unnatural. We have the chemo to kill all the bad stuff and in the process it kills some of the good stuff which makes us feel rubbish for a time. You have to hold onto the fact that good stuff bounces back which makes the whole thing very doable. I had my last chemo last week. It's weird but going to my chemo unit became my "normal", seeing the nurses, receptionists and Macmillan volunteers. Everyone is very friendly and quite matter of fact about it all. I also saw the same people having treatment and we would chat and even laugh while tethered to our drips! I won't miss the chemo one bit but I will miss my "chemo family". I hope it all goes well for you. Take each day at a time, ride the side effects and enjoy the days when you fell well (of which there will be many so it's not all bad). xx
Posts.Title: not having a good day :(

Posts.Content: Hi everyone I hope you can help with my current problem. I had docetaxel at the beginning of Jan which among other things caused a bad case of oral thrush followed by a very sore mouth and lips. I lost a lot of skin from the roof of my mouth and it was very uncomfortable for a while. This has now healed well and I am now on Paclitaxel with no bad effects so far. My problem is that ever since I had the sore mouth, the roof of my mouth has been completely numb. I can't feel it and this affects how food tastes. Has anyone experienced anything similar? I am getting worried that I may be stuck with this as it has been this way for about a month now. xxx
Posts.Title: Numb mouth

Posts.Content: Try the sweet chilli and sour cream crisps. They've become another favourite of mine since I've only had half my tastebuds operational
Posts.Title: Numb mouth

Posts.Content: Hi Littlesusie. I know what you mean about the texture of bread. I've completely gone off it now and have become addicted to crispbreads and cheese
Posts.Title: Numb mouth

Posts.Content: All one flavour in the same crisp from Aldi. Gourmet hand cooked. Having cancer sure makes us focus on the important things in life don't you think!?
Posts.Title: Numb mouth

Posts.Content: It is natural to be scared as what we are going through is so unnatural. We have the chemo to kill all the bad stuff and in the process it kills some of the good stuff which makes us feel rubbish for a time. You have to hold onto the fact that good stuff bounces back which makes the whole thing very doable. I had my last chemo last week. It's weird but going to my chemo unit became my "normal", seeing the nurses, receptionists and Macmillan volunteers. Everyone is very friendly and quite matter of fact about it all. I also saw the same people having treatment and we would chat and even laugh while tethered to our drips! I won't miss the chemo one bit but I will miss my "chemo family". I hope it all goes well for you. Take each day at a time, ride the side effects and enjoy the days when you fell well (of which there will be many so it's not all bad). xx
Posts.Title: not having a good day :(

Posts.Content: Has anybody experienced oral thrush when on chemo? My mouth feels like something has died in there! I went to Drs today and he said it was this and prescribed Nystan drops. If anyone has had this what did you take and did it clear up soon? I'm having trouble eating anything and it feels awful. I've just had my 4th chemo and first docetaxel so don't know if it's common to this but I know chemo can cause fungal infections. I'd appreciate any comments or help. Thanx xx
Posts.Title: Oral thrush side effect of chemo

Posts.Content: Thank you for your reply. It's good to know the nystatin works for this. Good luck with the tax. Xx
Posts.Title: Oral thrush side effect of chemo

Posts.Content: Thank you. I'm keeping an eye on it and will go to BCN if it gets any worse
Posts.Title: Post radiotherapy effects

Posts.Content: I had my last radiotherapy session on 12th May and all through it I didn't really have any side effects apart from a bit of itching. About 10 days after an itchy rash appeared on my breast and under it and this has gradually got a bit worse. My scar under my armpit is also very red and sore although it doesn't itch because it is numb there. I have been applying E45 all the time and hydrocortisone cream that the onc prescribed but it doesn't seem to be clearing up. I was told I may get a sunburn effect but this isn't like that. Also, why is my scar affected Has anyone else experienced this and is it normal?
Posts.Title: Post radiotherapy effects

Posts.Content: Hi Ro. It sounds like what I'm experiencing is normal if you have similar problems. I only had a WLE and axilliary clearance but I still have to do the arm exercises as it gets tight if I don't. We are like microwave meals - cooking from the inside out!. X
Posts.Title: Post radiotherapy effects

Posts.Content: Hi. Just giving my post a boost in the hope of a reply.
Posts.Title: Continuing low blood count - please help!

Posts.Content: Thanks mistymoley and  theloneranger for your advice. Jan
Posts.Title: Continuing low blood count - please help!

Posts.Content: I'm meant to be having weekly paclitaxel and have only had 2 out of 6 so far. For the last 3 weeks my chemo has been cancelled because my white blood cell count is too low. I was told the result of the blood test today and it still hasn't increased at all. I'm really worried that being neutropenic for so long is making me more and more at risk of infection. Also my treatment is now at a standstill and I feel I will never be at the end of it. Has anyone else experienced continuing low blood counts and what treatment did you have to rectify the problem? They won't give me the neulasta injection as it isn't licensed for paclitaxel. Thanks x
Posts.Title: Continuing low blood count - please help!

Posts.Content: Yes go for it. A dog is a great comfort when you are going through this and also a great deal of fun to lift your mood. They also keep you active by making sure you get out for a walk in the fresh air every day. As others have said, be sensible about hygiene and you should have no problems. I wouldn't be without my Dougal throughout all this (he is on my avatar). X
Posts.Title: Silly Question??

Posts.Content: Hi Scribblinglady. Unfortunately it is quite common to have a second operation so don't worry if this is the case. I had a 2nd op to clear margins and I also had one node infected of the 5 they took in the SNB. Finding out about the node came as a great shock as I just wasn't expecting this. I thought I'd have radiotherapy and that would be me cured! I've since realised it doesn't work like that. I was in bits at the thought of having chemo because of the infected node, but the panic eventually turns to acceptance as you concentrate on getting through each step. I had to have an axillary clearance in the 2nd op but all other nodes were clear. My advice is to take each step/news as calmly as you can, ask as many questions of your BCN and medical team as you can and keep away from Google! Remember, whatever your diagnosis or situation is, you will find plenty of lovely people on here with the same experiences to help you through. Good luck with biopsy results! Xx
Posts.Title: They didn't say this before!

Posts.Content: A great big fat WOOHOO!
Posts.Title: I did it too!
